Got Good English? Got! But Singapore Has Doubts Singapore's leaders have launched the Speak Good English Movement, a campaign to eliminate a rough-and-ready patois known as Singlish, one of many offspring of the English language known to linguists as Englishes.

Bush Meets Koizumi of Japan President Bush and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi met for the first time and agreed that their governments would ''explore'' restarting negotiations over global warming, months after Mr. Bush declared the previous accord ''dead.''
INTERNATIONAL

Got Good English? Got! But Singapore Has Doubts Singapore's leaders have launched the Speak Good English Movement, a campaign to eliminate a rough-and-ready patois known as Singlish, one of many offspring of the English language known to linguists as Englishes.

Bush Meets Koizumi of Japan President Bush and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi met for the first time and agreed that their governments would ''explore'' restarting negotiations over global warming, months after Mr. Bush declared the previous accord ''dead.''

A United States Air Force sergeant who has become the main suspect in the rape of a Japanese woman in Okinawa last week was released without being charged after a second day of questioning, the police said.
Security Push in Japan Schools After a man killed eight children at an elementary school last month, schools have adopted security measures that until the attack would have been unthinkable.

Serb Leader's Transfer Account Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic said that he feared the army would try to stop the transfer of Slobodan Milosevic to an international tribunal this week and that he had set up an elaborate series of ruses and decoys to spirit the former president out of the country.

Turkey's Education Deficit Two-thirds of Turkey's 66 million people are under age 35 -- a huge potential resource for a developing economy -- but deficiencies in the centralized national education system have left many without skills.
NATIONAL

Heart Regulator Implanted In Vice President's Chest Vice President Dick Cheney left the hospital after doctors implanted a sophisticated defibrillator device in his chest, the third cardiac procedure Mr. Cheney has undergone since the election in November.

Eco-Sabotage Is Rising Federal authorities report a growing pattern of eco-sabotage, with anonymous break-ins at genetic-engineering laboratories or arson at logging sites. Companies large and small are increasing security against the perpetrators, who say they are acting in defense of the environment.

Blacks a New Power in Suburb Washington, D.C., has been steadily losing tens of thousands of blacks as they pursue the suburban dream. In their exodus, they have built a new black majority in nearby Prince George's County, Md.

Work on Beaches Faulted Congress is ignoring a call by President Bush to put the brakes on transplanting sand to eroded beaches, work that costs billions and that even the Army Corps of Engineers concedes is fruitless.

Tentative Airline Settlement Negotiators for American Airlines and its flight attendants agreed on a tentative contract, federal mediators said. Flight attendants had rejected a tentative agreement in 1999 and have been without a contract ever since.
Smithsonian Plan Reversed A Senate committee has voted to keep open a Smithsonian Institution center that researches the conservation of art, reversing a decision by the secretary of the institution.
NEW YORK/REGION

Bloomberg, in an Interview, Seems More Like a Democrat Michael R. Bloomberg is seeking the Republican nomination for mayor of New York, but the candidate on display during a 70-minute interview at his sleek and spotless campaign headquarters appeared far closer on the issues to his Democratic rivals than to any Republican, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

Seeking Officers to Be Nurses A New York health care company has turned to an unlikely talent pool as a way of ending the local shortage of nurses. The Visiting Nurse Service of New York is recruiting police officers and firefighters, many of whom retire young and seek second careers.

Albany Gives Help to Poor In a year notable mostly for stalemate, the New York State Legislature has quietly passed a flurry of bills to aid the poor. Advocates for the poor say that the bills represent the greatest step the Legislature has taken in years.

OBITUARIES
Chet Atkins A versatile guitarist and record producer who was a leader in the growth of Nashville as a music center in the 1950's and part of the force that transformed country music, he was 77.
Rabbi Ira Eisenstein A key figure in the creation of the Reconstructionist movement in American Judaism, he was 94.
James T. Ellis A computer scientist who was one of the creators of an electronic discussion network that helped spur the growth of the Internet, he was 45.
